thread.title: ATO hits record in winding-up applications
thread.title_full: ATO hits record in winding-up applications | afr.com

author: Marianna Papadakis
title: ATO hits record in winding-up applications
text:
Around 38 winding-up applications were lodged by the ATO on Friday alone. by Marianna Papadakis Insolvency experts say the record number of winding-up applications filed by the Australian Taxation Office in the past six months is indicative of an aggressive approach taken towards struggling businesses and means legal action forcing companies to pay up or go into liquidation will continue to rise.
An ATO spokeswoman said it was not "cracking down small business" as some claimed, but was taking a balanced, fair and supportive approach to ensure that all small businesses meet their tax obligations.
Figures compiled by Insolvency Notices, which tracks insolvencies and bankruptcies, showed there were 568 wind-up applications in September, following 582 wind-ups filed in May and well exceeding the ATO's long term average of 92 a month.
"We are focused on making it as easy as possible for businesses, and other taxpayers, to understand and meet their tax obligations," she said.
The spokeswoman said there were about 1000 ATO-initiated small business wind-ups last year though there was a greater focus on legal action in the second half of the 2014/15 year with around 1200 wind up actions filed in this period.
The September figures show the worst affected states were NSW and Victoria and even more worrying is the figures do not yet reflect a significant decline in mining services in Western Australia which could cause a spike in the statistics in coming months.
Jamieson Louttit & Associates insolvency and advisory partner Jamieson Louttit said it appeared the ATO was on a "war path" against small business and he believed director penalty and garnishee notices, issued by the ATO, had also risen significantly.
"It could reflect that the Federal Government is short of cash. There's no other explanation for it," he said. "It's hurting small business, that's where it is principally targeted."
 Mr Louttit said the ATO reduction in the threshold at which it pursued small businesses that owed it debts, from $300,000 to around $30,000 was hitting small business hard.
"The phone runs off the hook when they come through, the economy is really struggling and I just don't know how they are going to turn it around," he said.â€‹
Peter Marsden a partner, at accounting and consultancy firm RSM Bird Cameron, agreed the numbers reflected a more aggressive approach from the ATO, but he said this was not a negative thing.
The ATO was starting to call in a massive $35 billion in debts owed to it, which it should have been collecting some time ago, Mr Marsden said.
Of that outstanding tax debt around $20 billion is owed by small and medium sized enterprises.
Mr Marsden agreed the problem had been government policy.
"It stems back to the global financial crisis and an unwillingness to wind-up trading businesses then, that's resulted in a large build of debt," he said.
The high number of winding-ups was likely to continue through Christmas and the new year.
"Whatever happens after that depends on any improvement in the economy," he said.
"Growth is stagnant so companies are finding it difficult to make positive decisions to generate profit."
